definitions.definition: to stop and hold a moving object or person, especially in your hands

examples.text: She managed to catch the keys as they fell.
I caught him when he tripped.
The dog caught the stick in its mouth.
I threw the bag in the air and she caught it.
‘Throw me over that towel, will you?’ ‘OK. Catch!’

definitions.definition: to hold a liquid when it falls

examples.text: The roof was leaking and I had to use a bucket to catch the drips.

definitions.definition: to take hold of somebody/something

examples.text: He **caught hold of** her arm as she tried to push past him.
He caught her up in his arms.
She caught the bar with both hands as she fell.

definitions.definition: to be in time for a bus, train, plane, etc. and get on it

examples.text: to **catch a bus/train/flight**
We caught the 12.15 from Oxford.
I must go—I have a train to catch.
After a while they left to catch their bus.
He was still hoping to catch the 8.30 ferry.
If you want to catch that bus, you'd better hurry!
Then she had to leave to catch her plane.
He was thinking of catching a plane home.

definitions.definition: to capture a person or an animal that tries or would try to escape

examples.text: The murderer was never caught.
Our cat is hopeless at catching mice.
How many **fish did you catch**?
The police say they are doing all they can to catch the culprits.

definitions.definition: to get an illness

examples.text: It is unusual to catch measles more than once.
I think I must have caught this cold from you.

definitions.definition: if something catches your attention, etc., you notice it and feel interested in it
definitions.sensetop: catch somebody’s attention, imagination, interest, etc.

examples.text: A sign on the wall **caught my attention**.
Over the years, the mystery has caught the popular imagination.
There was one story in particular that caught her interest.

definitions.definition: to notice something only for a moment

examples.text: She **caught sight** of a car in the distance.
He **caught a glimpse** of himself in the mirror.
I caught a look of surprise on her face.
He caught a whiff of her perfume.

definitions.definition: to hear or understand something

examples.text: Sorry, I didn't quite catch what you said.

definitions.definition: to find or discover somebody doing something, especially something wrong
definitions.sensetop: catch somebody doing somethingcatch yourself doing somethingcatch somebody + adv./prep.

examples.text: I caught her lying to me again.
**You wouldn't catch me** working *(= I would never work)* on a Sunday!
She caught herself wondering whether she had made a mistake.
He was caught with bomb-making equipment in his home.
Mark walked in and **caught them at it** *(= in the act of doing something wrong)*.
thieves **caught in the act**
You've caught me at a bad time *(= at a time when I am busy)*.

definitions.definition: to be in time to do something, talk to somebody, etc.

examples.text: I caught him just as he was leaving the building.
I was hoping to catch you at home *(= to see you at home when you were there)*.
The illness can be treated provided it's caught *(= discovered)* early enough.
to **catch the post** *(= post letters before the box is emptied)*
Bye for now! I'll **catch you later** *(= speak to you again later)*.

definitions.definition: to see or hear something; to attend something

examples.text: Let's eat now and maybe we could catch a movie later.
Did you catch that show on the radio?

definitions.definition: to happen unexpectedly and put somebody in a difficult situation

examples.text: His arrival **caught** me **by surprise**.
She **got caught in** a thunderstorm.

definitions.definition: to become stuck in or on something; to make something become stuck

examples.text: Her dress caught on a nail.
He caught his thumb in the door.

definitions.definition: to hit somebody/something
definitions.sensetop: catch somebody/something + adv./prep.catch somebody a blow + adv./prep.

examples.text: The stone caught him on the side of the head.
She caught him a blow on the chin.

definitions.definition: to begin to burn

examples.text: The wooden rafters **caught fire**.
These logs are wet: they won't catch.

definitions.definition: if something catches the light or the light catches it, the light shines on it and makes it shine too

examples.text: The knife gleamed as it **caught the light**.
A colourful glow appears as the light catches the glass.

definitions.definition: if you catch the sun, you become red or brown because of spending time in the sun
to show or describe something accurately

examples.text: The artist has caught her smile perfectly.
Cameras caught Jessica headed to a photo shoot downtown.

definitions.definition: to make a player unable to continue batting by catching the ball they have hit before it touches the ground
to be involved in an argument or fight between two other people or groups

examples.text: When they quarrel, I am often caught in the middle.

definitions.definition: to suddenly feel a strong need to go to the toilet
to be put at a disadvantage
to be in a difficult situation when any action you take will have bad results
in a situation where you have to choose between two things, both of which are unpleasant
to stop breathing for a moment because of fear, shock, etc.

examples.text: When he said he had resigned, I caught my breath in surprise.

definitions.definition: to start to be able to breathe normally again after running or doing exercise that makes you tired
to become ill with a cold
to have problems

examples.text: The film caught a cold over the outstanding debt.

definitions.definition: to catch a very bad cold
to attract somebody’s attention

examples.text: Can you catch the waiter's eye?

definitions.definition: to attract or please somebody

examples.text: She looked through the hotel advertisements until one of them caught her fancy.

definitions.definition: to be punished or spoken to angrily about something

examples.text: If your dad finds out you'll really catch it!

definitions.definition: to get an advantage over somebody by doing something when they are not expecting it and not ready for it
to surprise somebody by doing something when they are not expecting it and not ready for it
to upset somebody by reminding them of something they are particularly sensitive about
to catch somebody in the act of doing something wrong or committing a crime
to arrive or do something when somebody is not expecting it and not ready, especially when they are in an embarrassing situation
the person who takes the opportunity to do something before other people will have an advantage over them
to make somebody unsteady and in danger of falling

examples.text: I was thrown off balance by the sudden gust of wind.
The sudden movement threw him off balance.

definitions.definition: to make somebody surprised and no longer calm

examples.text: The senator was clearly caught off balance by the unexpected question.

definitions.definition: (to put somebody) at a disadvantage or in difficulty

examples.text: Advances in drone technology have caught lawmakers on the back foot.
The side that’s on the back foot, struggling to defend, will usually give away more penalties.
We'd like to put the fossil fuel industry on the back foot.

wordOrigin: Middle English (also in the sense ‘chase’): from Anglo-Norman French and Old Northern French cachier, variant of Old French chacier, based on Latin captare ‘try to catch’, from capere ‘take’.
